newsitem.title: USA: Orange Cty Transport Authority sues Goldman Sachs.
newsitem.headline: Orange Cty Transport Authority sues Goldman Sachs.

text.p: The Orange County, Calif., Transportation Authority has sued Goldman Sachs & Co. for allegedly failing to warn it about the risks in the county's investment portfolio, attorneys for the agency said Sunday.
The authority did not specify damages.
The authority alleged in the lawsuit, filed last week in Orange County Superior Court, that the firm was aware of the county's risky strategy, but did not warn the authority.
The lawsuit said Goldman Sachs should have informed the authority of the risks because the firm was an underwriter and dealer of authority debt.
The authority accused the firm of breaching its fiduciary duties and negligence, its attorneys said.
A spokesperson for Goldman Sachs was not immediately available to comment on the suit.
In November, the transportation authority sued auditor KPMG Peat Marwick LLP, alleging that the firm misrepresented the liquidity of the assets in the county portfolio.
Orange County filed for bankruptcy protection on Dec. 6, 1994, after sustaining losses of more than $1.6 billion on risky investments. The county emerged from bankruptcy in June.

The Orange County Transportation Authority, which provides bus and other transportation services and funds local freeway construction, said it had deposited about $1 billion in the county portfolio before its collapse.

The authority lost more than $225 million when the county's investments crashed in 1994, according to spokesman John Standiford. In its KPMG action, Standiford said the authority was seeking at least $400 million.
